item.title: Who we help
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded:
In 20018/19 Hearts & Minds visited 24 healthcare units and schools across Scotland.

We visited over 10,000 people suffering adversity between the ages of 6 months and 98 years, bringing them lightness and joy when they needed it most.

item.title: About us
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded: We are a Scottish charity that improves the wellbeing of people experiencing adversity through the art of therapeutic clowning.

item.title: Improving lives one smile at a time
item.dc:creator: danelder

item.title: Accessibility statement
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded:
Hearts & Minds Limited is committed to ensuring digital accessibility for people with disabilities. We are continually improving the user experience for everyone, and applying the relevant accessibility standards. 

Conformance status

The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) defines requirements for designers and developers to improve accessibility for people with disabilities. It defines three levels of conformance: Level A, Level AA, and Level AAA. Hearts & Minds is partially conformant with WCAG 2.1 level AA. Partially conformant means that some parts of the content do not fully conform to the accessibility standard.

Feedback

We welcome your feedback on the accessibility of Hearts & Minds. Please let us know if you encounter accessibility barriers on Hearts & Minds:

  • E-mail: info@heartsminds.org.uk
  • Postal address: Lower Ground, 4 Castle Terrace, Edinburgh, EH1 2DP

We try to respond to feedback within 5 business days.

item.title: Children with loved ones living with cancer
item.dc:creator: danelder

item.title: Children in SEN schools
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded:
Children with complex and severe learning disabilities can be isolated and miss out on meaningful human connections and playful interactions. Clowndoctors visit Special Educational Needs schools and use their improvisational skills and expertise in non-verbal communication to connect with the child behind the condition or set of behaviours, and celebrate their unique humanity.

Benefits of our visits to Special Educational Needs schools include:

  • giving access to performing arts and musical activities
  • providing an outlet for creativity and expression
  • allowing children to feel empowered and in control
  • providing an opportunity to play
  • overcome feelings of anxiety, isolation and boredom
  • improve self-esteem and self confidence

Our work in Special Education Schools is delivered over the course of the school year, allowing Clowndoctors to build meaningful relationships with each child, empowering them to reach their full potential. Our Clowndoctors in the Classroom programme has been made in collaboration with Beatlie and Mavisbank Schools, is in-line with Curriculum for Excellence and GIRFEC.

item.title: Children in hospital
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded:
Hospital environments and medical interventions can be frightening and intimidating for children, whatever their age. The Clowndoctors connect with young people, celebrate their humanity and create a space for them to feel lightness and joy.

Clowndoctors help children and young people in hospital to:

  • overcome feelings of powerlessness, anxiety, isolation and boredom
  • improve self-esteem and self-confidence tackle communication, social and physical challenges
  • cope with painful, distressing or confusing treatments and procedures
  • be playful and re-connect to their imaginations and humour
  • allow family and staff to see them relaxed, happy, laughing and playful

Based on staff referrals, each intervention is made to measure and improvised. Empathy, authenticity and playfulness sit at the heart of our approach. We use music, singing, magic, puppetry, slapstick or imaginative play to demystify the hospital environment and medical procedures and ignite imaginations and playfulness. With the Clowndoctors, hospitalised children can experience control over their circumstance and experience.

Our Clowndoctors programme focusses on both long and short stay patients in Oncology, Renal, Orthopaedic, Neurology, Cardiology, intensive and high dependency care wards.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: "She's been in pain for so long it's so nice to see her smile again"

Bec graduated with a B.A. in Communications (Theatre/Media) from Charles Stuart University in Australia. She has since studied with Philippe Gaulier and Angela de Castro. She has worked with Giant Productions, Te Pooka arts collective and Licketyspit theatre company.

Fiona trained at The Royal Conservatoire of Scotland. Her work with Fish and Game theatre company, including The Polar Bears Go Wild, has been performed at Unicorn Theatre, Imaginate and Take Off theatre festivals. Fiona trained in clowning with Phillippe Gaulier and John Wright

item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded: During a visit to Borders General Hospital the Elderflowers went to visit a lady who can sometimes be very vocal and is usually in her room...

item.title: A family get-together for Doris
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded: In her 70s, and in the early stages of dementia, Doris gets confused and angry and is particularly fixated on going home to see her family...

item.title: The Power of Music
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded: Two of our Elderflowers, Spud and Dippsy, recently had visit with a lady in her 70s whom we have known for some time. Sometimes she is...

item.title: Drawing as a tool for reflective practice
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded:
As part of my artistic practice, for the last three years or so, Ive used drawing as a way of recording visits. Better than words can, the drawings help me to connect back to a moment of creative spark or connection that Id like to build on in future. It is direct and unfiltered and immediate in a way that writing cant be. I dont have to choose the right words or follow any rules.

I think Rebecca Swift puts the value of drawing as reflective practice very eloquently in a recent blog for Entelechy Arts, They can make what is harder to see, more visible. They distil complex, contradictory and layered dynamics into one frame, so you can see several things happening at once. They illustrate aspects of our experience we might smooth over in the verbal telling

Below is a selection of entries from my journal. When reflecting on my day, I allow an image to emerge in my mind and attempt to represent it, trusting that its resonance is significant and of use.

Above left:This image represents a visit with a gentleman with very advanced Dementia. We had never heard him use verbal language. In this interaction, he vocalised along with our singing, and at the end said very clearly, Good. His voice sent vibrations through the room.

Above right: A reminder of the gift of our vulnerability as clowns. Stepping up on an imaginary stage to sing her heart out, Bonnie Elderflower was promptly told to Get off! by one lady, much to the amusement of the other ladies and gentlemen in the room.

Below: A joyful foot dance with a gentleman who loved to dance but who could no longer stand.

Below: A sensory visit with a boy with profound autism. A reminder to breath. To allow stillness. To trust silence.

Below left: A visit with a gentleman with Dementia in a locked ward for patients who display behaviours that challenge. I was struck by the poetic delicacy of his words, is that representative of the Sun? and the care with which he wound the fabric with me.

Below right: A useful reminder of how effective simplicity is.

My three years of journal entries are as varied in their content as the interactions I have on the floor. They are a record of some of the most profound moments of connection and joy I have been lucky enough to experience in this work, as well as moments of difficulty and sadness. They help me to process, to remember, to learn and to let go.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Zoe is now retired but previously worked as an organisation change consultant and executive director in the public and voluntary sectors. She is Chair and non Executive Director of a number of arts organisations in Scotland and the UK including Dancers Career Development, the Lamp of Lothian and the Scottish Chamber Orchestra. She has been Chair of Hearts and Minds for over 5 years and will step down from this position in 2019.

item.title: First section
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded:
We believe that meaningful human connection is vital for wellbeing, and that this is especially important when we are at our most vulnerable.

Hearts and Minds provide outstanding quality therapeutic clowning to paediatric wards, special education schools and dementia units across Scotland in order to improve the experience of children, people living with dementia, family and staff.

We cant change the progression of a disease, but we can transform experiences of adversity for the better by connecting to peoples humanity and giving them space to feel lightness and joy.

item.title: Second section
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded:
We do this by providing high quality and robust ongoing training to our professional practitioners, ensuring that we deliver outstanding practice in every visit we undertake. Our artists are committed, long-term members of the team resulting in consistency and continuity for our partners.

We build strong partnerships to better understand the circumstances and context of the environment we are in, ensuring the continuity and stability of our programmes, and creating buy-in - making sure that our partners get the best out of the work we do.

We seek to achieve best practice by always striving to improve, by being accountable and constantly measuring performance.

Our collaborative approach makes it possible to tailor our work for each individual setting and person we visit. Collaboration in planning and developing future programmes ensures that we consistently deliver the best service possible to the healthcare units and schools that we work in.

item.title: Collaboration
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded: We collaborate with our partners in order to tailor our practice to suit individuals, healthcare units & schools at all times. We are open and active listeners, are respectful of the environments in which we work and we value honest feedback and communication.

item.title: Artistic integrity
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded: We know that only the highest quality therapeutic clown practice can make the positive impact we believe is possible. We receive regular artistic training and coaching that is specific to the environments we work in and the people we visit. We undertake regular reflective practice undergo regular team supervision sessions to avoid 'burn-out'.

item.title: Kindness
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded: Kindness is woven into our every interaction at Hearts & Minds. Within our team and towards others, we are friendly, generous and considerate. We celebrate the success of our partners, offer help where we can, and are courageous and honest in giving and receiving feedback.

item.title: Empathy
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded: Empathy helps us step into the shoes of the people we work with and for and create interactions that are meaningful at all times. We listen actively, are emotionally open, are mindful of our environment and are non-judgemental at all times.

item.title: Playfulness
item.dc:creator: danelder
item.content:encoded: Playfulness it is at the heart of what it is to be human and to be a clown. We believe in the power of play to help us face adversity with openness, creativity and humour. We create invitations to play wherever we go, and connect with the vital spark of each person we meet.
